etymologies: late Middle English (in the sense ‘make thin’): from Latin extenuat- ‘made thin’, from the verb extenuare (based on tenuis ‘thin’)

senses.definition: (of a factor or situation) acting in mitigation to lessen the seriousness of guilt or an offence
senses.example: hunger and poverty are not treated by the courts as extenuating circumstances

etymologies: late Middle English (in the sense ‘announce publicly’): from Latin divulgare, from di- ‘widely’ + vulgare ‘publish’ (from vulgus ‘common people’)

senses.example: I do not want to divulge my plans at the moment

etymologies: mid 16th century: from French persistance, from the verb persister; influenced in spelling by Latin persistent- ‘continuing steadfastly’

senses.definition: the fact of continuing in an opinion or course of action in spite of difficulty or opposition
senses.example: Cardiff's persistence was rewarded with a try

senses.definition: the continued or prolonged existence of something
senses.example: the persistence of huge environmental problems

etymologies: late 18th century: probably a shortening of obsolete extravage ‘digress, ramble’
1949: the name of an artificial official language in George Orwell's Nineteen Eighty-Four

senses.definition: ambiguous euphemistic language used chiefly in political propaganda
senses.example: ‘deterrence’ is just Newspeak for plain old threatening

etymologies: mid 16th century: from French portemanteau, from porter ‘carry’ + manteau ‘mantle’

senses.definition: a large travelling bag, typically made of stiff leather and opening into two equal parts.
a word blending the sounds and combining the meanings of two others, for example motel or brunch
senses.example: podcast is a portmanteau, a made-up word coined from a combination of the words iPod and broadcast

senses.definition: middle-aged, but typically still maintaining the interests and activities of younger people.

etymologies: early 19th century: from French, from fusiller ‘to shoot’, from fusil (see fusil)

senses.definition: a series of shots fired or missiles thrown all at the same time or in quick succession
senses.example: marchers had to dodge a fusillade of missiles

etymologies: early 17th century: from Turkish şerbet, Persian šerbet, from Arabic šarba ‘drink’, from šariba ‘to drink’. Compare with syrup

senses.definition: a flavoured sweet effervescent powder eaten alone or made into a drink
senses.example: disks of fruit-flavoured rice paper filled with sherbet

senses.definition: (especially in Arab countries) a cooling drink of sweet diluted fruit juices
senses.example: the ladies floated around in diaphanous silks and served sherbet and other refreshments
I went down the local pub for a few sherbets
